posts.name: mischmitz@uni-osnabrueck.de
posts.cooked:
What I have read about Signal is very positive so far. Apart from privacy, I think that sustainability would be an important issue to tackle especially keeping in mind that Signal is currently growing.

I think of using renewable energy for servers, trying to optimize processes for computing efficiency and also examine hardware and where it comes from and how it is produced.

I am sure many people on here have more ideas, and look forward to reading more about this.

I 100% agree. I ask people to use Signal because it‚Äôs run by a not-for-profit and it‚Äôs more ethical as a result. However, if I could tell people that it‚Äôs also better for the environment (carbon negative, or servers run on renewable energy, or something similar), I think that would be a lovely selling point to new users, and one which could be more easily understood than the privacy benefits.

It would also be something I‚Äôd value as an existing user.

posts.name: link ‚ú¶
posts.cooked:
Related topic:

European Servers (less latency more green energy) Feature Requests
Me and my Signal fanboys have done a little research on the server infrastructure of Signal. I‚Äôm not going to post all the details but it seems that all messaging servers are concentrated in AWS‚Äôs Virginia data centers. In terms of latency I think it would be nice to have some servers here in Europe as well, so this is a feature request for them And while AWS has committed to using more clean energy, the data centers in Virginia still rely heavily on dirty coal: https://www.datacent‚Ä¶

link_counts.title: European Servers (less latency more green energy)

posts.cooked: Signal doesn‚Äôt track user metadata and they say No to government requests, so they probably have a lower carbon footprint compared to WhatsApp etc who deal with reported messages and secret government requests.

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked: I actually hope they use MORE fossil fuel.
Hopefully WhatsApp, Telegram etc use renewable energy sources like solar or wind, but Signal would still have lower energy use

posts.name: mischmitz@uni-osnabrueck.de
posts.cooked:
@Aku-Stable I agree that probably Telegram an Whatsapp might have a bigger impact.
Nontheless in terms of privacy Signal has pressured competitors like Whatsapp to improve on that, and maybe something analogous could happen if Signal commits more and more openly to sustainability.

posts.name: Jeremy

We already had a thread about this issue. Currently Apple‚Äòs iMessage is the only green service that does not pollute the atmosphere.

Will Signal soon run on 100% renewable energy? Off Topic
I‚Äòm proud to announce that I‚Äòve just taken an important step to make Signal run on 100% renewable energy Just kidding guys, but I‚Äòm so frustrated that AWS is such a lagger when it comes to clean energy. Compared with Apple‚Äôs iMessage (100% RE*) for me it‚Äòs kind of a drawback that AWS-backed apps like Signal run on dirty coal. *Apples still needs to buy AWS, because they screwed up their data center in Ireland. https://twitter.com/cfkress/status/1126790862166478848?s=21

posts.name: James Baggott
posts.cooked: My favorite eco-friendly server companies are GreenGeeks, DreamHost, and SiteGround. Idk if Signal would be able to use their services though.

posts.name: mischmitz@uni-osnabrueck.de
posts.cooked: Sounds interesting, why are they your favorite server companies?

I wanted to post the same suggestion but it was labelled as duplicate, so maybe we can revive this thread. I really believe it is of great importance and I am quite surprised that this hasn‚Äôt been talked about since 2021.

Recently, I have changed my email provider and choosing a 100% green energy provider was an important point in deciding where to go. The same could apply here.

Signal committing to move to servers using 100% green energy would not only be a good ‚Äúsignal‚Äù to other messaging apps to be more ecological but is also a powerful way to attract more people to use the app.
